title: How to Buy Baby Furniture

steps.headline: Measure the room and consider furniture placement.
steps.description:
Use a tape measure or a laser measurer and measure the size of your nursery. Pay specific attention to wall space, as most of your furniture will go along the wall. Think about where you will place:
Your crib. A standard crib is about 4 to 5 feet (1 to 2 m) (1.2 to 1.5 m) long. A changing table. Changing tables can be between 3 and 5 feet (0.9 and 1.5 m) long. A rocking chair. You’ll probably need 3 to 4 feet (.9 to 1.2 m) of wall space for a rocking chair.

steps.headline: Pick a theme and color scheme.
steps.description: Before purchasing baby furniture, you’ll want to decide on a theme and color scheme. This is important, as you’ll want all the furniture to fit together into your plan for the room. Look on websites like Pinterest and Parenting.com for ideas about how to decorate your baby's room. Some themes include animals, outdoors, and fairytales. If you decide on a certain color, like white, pink, or baby blue, you’ll likely want to purchase all your furniture in that color. You may want to consider purchasing a set so everything matches.

steps.headline: Order furniture in the second trimester.
steps.description: Although it may be tempting to start ordering baby furniture very early on during your pregnancy, you should wait until the second trimester (between 3 and 6 months) to do so. By waiting, you’ll be able to confirm the sex of the baby and make sure that your pregnancy is normal and healthy.

steps.headline: Purchase your crib first.
steps.description: If you’re buying pieces of furniture individually, purchase the crib first. Since the crib is the centerpiece of the entire nursery, you’ll want to match everything to it. Ultimately, your crib style will help you decide on many other items you’ll need for the nursery. Some types of cribs include: standard cribs, portable cribs, and multipurpose cribs (that include a changing table). You could also choose a crib that converts to a toddler bed or full-size bed so your child can use it for years to come. The major styles of cribs are traditional (these usually have intricate woodwork) and modern (these are often very angular).

steps.headline: List all of the essential and optional furniture you may need.
steps.description:
Your final step in planning your nursery is to list all of the furniture you intend to get. This way, you'll know exactly what you want and you'll be able to plan where you'll put each piece. Include items like a:
Crib
Changing table
Dresser
Rocking chair
Small table to put next to the rocking chair
Bookshelf

steps.headline: Purchase furniture that meets current safety standards.
steps.description: While it may be tempting to purchase used furniture to save money or antique furniture for its character, many older pieces of baby furniture don’t meet current safety standards. This is important, as old furniture may put your baby at risk of injury or even death. Check each piece of furniture for recalls to ensure your baby’s safety. In the U.S., you can see a list of recalled items at https://www.cpsc.gov/Recalls. Slats on cribs shouldn’t be spaced more than 2 and 3/8 inches (60 mm) apart. Use a changing table that has cabinets or drawers so potentially hazardous products will be out of reach of your baby. Focus on furniture with round edges or purchase caps that cover sharp edges. While you can consider certain older pieces of furniture, like rocking chairs, make sure you verify that they are sturdy.

steps.headline: Avoid putting items into your crib.
steps.description: While you may be tempted to pile pillows and other items in the crib to make it more comfortable, do not. To meet current safety standards, your crib should have nothing in it but a mattress and a tight sheet. Don't use crib bumpers. The American Academy of Pediatrics warns that crib bumpers may cause sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS). Do not allow your baby to sleep with a blanket or a pillow. Avoid leaving toys in a baby's crib while they sleep.

steps.headline: Use furniture designed for babies.
steps.description: Although you may be handy around the house or like hand-made baby furniture, you need to make sure that all the furniture you purchase is specially designed for a nursery. This is important, as sharp edges and other features on furniture could pose safety hazards to your child. Be sure to use the anchors included with the furniture to anchor each piece to the wall so it doesn’t fall over and cause injuries or damage.

steps.headline: Create a budget.
steps.description: Tally up the total amount of money you have for your nursery furniture. Once you do this, you’ll have a good idea of what type of items you can buy and what you can’t buy. Remember, it is not worth going into debt for the best baby furniture when you can afford a safe alternative. You should be able to buy necessary furniture (a crib and mattress, changing table, and a dresser) for about $300.

steps.headline: Shop around.
steps.description:
The prices on baby furniture vary greatly. This depends on the quality of the item and where you buy it. As a result, before you pick anything you should determine the cost of items in your area. Check various stores and websites to find the most reasonable prices. Consider:
Crib mattresses can range from $40 to $350. Cribs may range from $110 to $800. A changing table could cost you between $60 and $200. Gliders and rockers could cost you between $100 and $800.

steps.headline: Look for sales and deals.
steps.description:
After getting an idea of the cost of major items in your region, consider sales, coupons, and deals. These could dramatically decrease the cost of furniture you’ll need to buy. When hunting for deals:
Purchase remaining items that are on your baby registry. If you can wait until after the birth of your child, you might be able to score a 10% or greater discount on your remaining registry items. Watch for nursery furniture sales at popular chains like Target, Babies "R" Us, and IKEA.

steps.headline: Buy a dresser that can function as a changing table.
steps.description: A great way to save money is to buy a dresser that you can also use as a changing table. This way, you’ll save space and money. In addition, you won’t need to get rid of your changing table when your baby outgrows it. If possible, anchor the dresser/changing table to the wall to ensure it doesn’t tip over.

steps.headline: Buy furniture that is made to last.
steps.description: When picking baby furniture, choose pieces that are made of quality materials and are built to last. While this is important for safety, it is also important if you plan to use the furniture for another child or to pass it to someone else.

steps.headline: Pick items that your child can grow into.
steps.description: There are many pieces of baby furniture you can buy that your child can continue to use at various stages of their lives. By thinking long-term, you’ll save yourself money and the trouble of purchasing new furniture later. Buy a crib that converts into a toddler bed. Purchase a changing table that can double as a dresser or bookshelf. Find a dresser or chest of drawers that will be big enough to accommodate your child as a young adult.

steps.headline: Choose furniture that won't go out of style.
steps.description: If you're planning to use some of your baby furniture for several years, pick items that will be just as appealing in five or ten years. When doing this, consider color, style, and finish. Avoid adventurous styles. Instead, consider traditional furniture styles that have stood the test of time. Focus on relatively neutral colors like white, grey, or stained wood. For example, while a bright pink dresser may seem cool for your baby girl, it may not work when your child is in elementary school.
